noun.description: A long, sturdy piece of squared timber or metal spanning an opening or part of a building, usually to support the roof or floor above.
A ray or shaft of light.
examples: a beam of light flashed in front of her

noun.description: A radiant or good-natured look or smile.

verb.description: Transmit (a radio signal or broadcast) in a specified direction.
examples: beaming a distress signal into space
the TV station begins beaming into homes in the new year

verb.description: (of a light or light source) shine brightly.
Construct a ceiling with exposed beams.
examples: vaulted beamed ceilings in the family room

phrases: I know there's a beam in my eye, so it's too bad I so enjoy pointing out the specks in others.
But, of course, others out there can sometimes notice the blockage, like a beam in our eye.
The problem is that many people reverse this idea and argue that so long as we have the smallest mote in our eye, we cannot criticize another for having a beam in his eye.
He is a beam in my eye!
He does not think that he has a beam in his eye.
origin: Old English bÄ“am tree, beam, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch boom and German Baum.
